transcript.content: Travis, "Love Will Come Through" on XFM 104.9, I'm Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Karl Pilkington, etc. I've got some, uh, great tunes, actually, lined up--
I've brought in, uhh, some Aimee Mann, some, uh, Neil Young, I'm gonna play my favorite Clash track. What are you- what have you got for us, Steve?
I've got a dynamite, uh, hip hop tune--
By The Roots, which I think you'll enjoy.
Got a little bit of, uhh, Joni Mitchell, maybe swing that on later.
I nearly brought in some Joni Mitchell, it's a good job I didn't.
It wouldn't of made any difference. It wouldn't have made any difference.
No, we- we'd of probably played yours and--
With the tune of my ear.
Uh, Karl, what have you got lined up for us, as the producer?
No, I didn't have a full week off, I had three days off--
Because I was workin' all over Christmas.
And, uhh, still didn't stop working, preparin' stuff.
You've got a nice load of prizes there--
That I've sorted out. I had to come in here especially to sort that out.
Did you rifle through the drawers up at Capital Gold instead of down here?
Yeh. Yeah. Uhh, "Rockbusters" - we're still doin' that.
We've got that. Uhh, last week, ehmm, we sort of changed "Educating Ricky" a bit.... Ehm... just a little bit.
Don't say, "We". I don't want to be incriminated in it.
Well- well I "changed it" in the sense that rather than giving ya too much information about different things - it's hard to, sort of, keep it all in--
I'm givin' ya, sort of, information on one thing. So last- last week--
Yeah. No, cuz some of your stuff was a little bit too intense for me. Uh, my favorite story was, "There was a blind girl, she hit her head and got better", and I couldn't take all that in at once.
So, you really should ration some of the education.
Well we- we sort of start--
Wasn't last week, uh, war-related, uhh, stories?
Yeah, it was, uhh, "War Do You Think of That, Then?"
"War Do You Think of That, Then".
And it was the French, uh, battle cr- uh, goin' over the top was, "John's got a mustache".
Which you think was ambiguous because someone might have said that anyway.
Well, look, you've remembered it. So it's working.
So, we'll be doin' that and last week you said--
Loads of French people have just gone to war, who are listening to this.
You, uhh- you said you wanted to learn some science this week--
So- so, the title this week for that is: "A-cid I Would Sort You Some Science Out".
How long did that take you to come up with?
Listen, right, no- people- people love Karl. There's comedians coming up to me and go, "Karl is the funniest man"--
They absolutely love him, right. But, I think we're only seeing half of it, right.
If we can get him on television- his face, then, when he told me that title was like a child at Christmas.
It was- it was- he was so proud of it, he was excited what I was gonna- it was brilliant.
It's a bit like when a child's drawn a picture in art class: you- you know you've got to stick it on the fridge--
But you basically think it's crap.
(Laughing Slightly) It's very much like that.
We have got another one. Looking at, uhh, snails this week.
Because I know you're not a fan of snails, are you?
Well, after a bit of research, I found some good stuff ab- about, umm, like, they sleep for 13 years - some of 'em.
And that. So we'll be looking into that later--
Ricky, you tried that once, didn't you?
Which is something that I talk to you about--
Last- yeah, well last week's was brilliant.
It's good to have a flat head in India.
(Laughing) It's good to have a flat head in India. I forgot all about that.
Uhh, and, uhh, that's about it. That's--
Well I'm gonna- I'm gonna s- play one of my favorite Smith tracks--
Can I just, uhh- make a request though? I'd quite like - if you- if you've got time - to bring back, um - just for one week only - "White Van Karl".
Because there's some quite interesting topics this week.
Oh, is there things happening in the world?
Cuz Karl doesn't think there is.
"There is a Light That Never Goes Out"
The Smiths - There is a Light That Never Goes Out
As "There is a Light That Never Goes Out" fades out, a Slide Whistle is Playing Along
Someone's left one of those little things in here. It's brilliant, innit?!
It's amazing. What are they called, those things?
I just- I imagine there- just there I was thinking of being in the front row at a Morrissey concert and going, "I just- could I just play along?"
I don't know what kind of sound that is!
(Laughing) I don't know. It's only used for when Kenneth Williams...
Ricky Plays an "Up" Sound on the Slide Whistle
(Laughing) That's the only time that is used, that noise.
It's like it was specially created for the "Carry On" films.
(Laughing) Yeah. Yeah. "We need- I don't know what it is, but we need something when I walk in and see someone changing." "Well, what about this?"
Ricky Plays an "Up" Sound on the Slide Whistle

"There is a Light That Never Goes Out" by The Smiths. Um, I phoned, uh, Karl up, in the week, yeah? And, uhh, I said, uhh, "What are you doin'?", he went, "Well, even though it's one of me days off, I'm just doin' some research on the web". He went, "Yeah I found a thing- I think I'm doing science". And then he said, "You can get wigs for dogs in Tokyo".
That's his scientific fact. And I went, "What do you mean? You can get dogs- if they need a wig-", I said, "If they need a wig? What? Are dogs going bald?"
And he went, like this is fine to him- he went, "It's a stressful city, Tokyo."

The world's all right with Karl. He's always got an explanation. I've only ever seen him confused once when, in Edinburgh, he looked his window one day and he saw a bloke putting a parking ticket on some rubbish.
He couldn't work out- could ya?
And the ba- and the woman breast feeding her 8 year old child didn't- you didn't like, did ya?
No, didn't like that. But, umm, the whatshername- animals with wigs, I kinda thought- after I put the phone down to you, I thought about it and thought, "Yeah, it is a bit daft, that."
S- are you sure it's not the ageing pop group?
But when you think- have you ever seen, like, a bald pet?
Cuz me mam, ehm- we had a ca- we used to get through loads of cats cuz we lived on a--
(Laughing) OH GOD! He's starting early today, innit?!
(Laughing) What do you mean you got through a lot of cats?!
Just cuz- cuz we lived o- no we lived on--
(Laughing) Oh God, what do you mean???
No, we lived on, like, a main road.
So we used to get through a lot of 'em. Me dad kept saying, you know--
"Stop wasting money" - you know - "with- it's not good--"
Right, so, umm, anyway we had this cat that was ill all the time...
(Laughing Slightly) He's just a bag of nerves probably!
Vroom! Vroom! (Laughing) "Oh God. Bloody hell." Vroom!
D- don't let me go to the Pilkington's!
And he- he- for some reason it kept being sick all the time.
Yeah. That is nerves. That's definitely nerves.
So, me mam thought- kind of thought, "Oh, I've had enough of this" and she shaved it.

WHAT! WHOA! Whoah whoahhh whoah whoah whoah whoah whoah whoah. Now I know- I know you're not vets, in your family, but what correlation did your mum think there was between it being sick and shaving it?
Because it kept being sick and it was a pain to wash because it kept getting, sort of--
So she wanted a dry wipe cat.
Why didn't she just varnish it?
So now- so now he's cold and sick?
No but d- no, not- I mean, not all of it. She left, sort of, the back half but, sort of, from- from its waist, sort of t--
(Laughing) I love that! Shaving cuz it's sick on itself!
And it's the weirdest looking thing. I mean, nor- normally I like cats, I'm always, like, giving yours a stroke on the head and that.
As soon as she did that, it was like, "Oooh."
So now it's sick, cold and hated!
It must've- I mean, other- the other cats must've been taking the mick out of it constantly. It's just making things worse. Did it get- I'm hoping that it got run over and was put out of its misery.
No, I think it- I think it got all right, that one... Or is that the-? Yeah, it did get run over.
(Laughing Slightly) How many cats do you say you got through?
I'd say when it- whilst I was livin' at home- I mean, it- it's still on the increase even though I'm not living there--
So, I- whilst- whilst I was there - probably five.
And were you upset each time or you just got used to it?
It's- it's one of them things, innit, like I've said before when you first see something it's a bit of a shock, do you know what I mean? It's like the Elephant Man or whatever--
First time you see him it's that, sort of, "Oooh, look at that."
Do you remember the first time you saw Steve? No, I'm not being funny. Do you remember the- about the first...
Yeah, but I've said this before - it's always- then you get used to how people look and you don't--
(Laughing) I'm gonna burst! I'm gonna- you have to play a record because I just- Steve's face!
Goldrush - Let You Down Begins To Play
No, but I've got used to it.
"Let You Down", Goldrush on XFM 104.9. Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Karl Pilkington. Brilliant. A--
Rick, I was in a- I don't know whether I should tell you this because it might rock you to the very core...
But I was in an Indian restaurant the other night and, uhh- I don't- you've not seen the film- have you seen the film "Notting Hill"?
Right, in the film "Notting Hill"- have you seen that, Karl?
Do you remember the bit- uh, Julia Roberts plays a- a movie star rather like Julia Roberts--
She's the most famous movie- I yeah.
And she is in a restaurant having dinner with, uh, uhh, Hugh Grant and she overhears some people in the restaurant slagging her off and saying, you know--

She's a slapper probably, all actors are- all actresses are. And, uhh, she's, sort of, stewing on it and, uh, Hugh Grant wants to say something and she says, "No, I won't- I won't let you". And then as she's walking out, she goes and says something to them and of course their faces drop, they can't believe it's her. Anyway, I was in a Chin- you know, an Indian restaurant the other night and they were slagging you off, Rick.
Well they were s- all they were saying is they were going, "Aw, Ricky Gervais. The thing about Ricky Gervais is: he's just like the character he plays"

"He's just like David Brent in real life". Annd, I was listening in and I was thinking, "Well, I want to say something. I want to go over and have a word and say, you know, 'You're- you're partially right...'"
But, uhh- but I couldn't- I didn't know what to do- I didn't know- I didn't know what to say. I- I couldn't- what could I do? I couldn't really go over there and get into a rumble--
I want to say, "What do you mean that I'm like him?"
I use his face and his vocal chords--
But I mean, I- I can't help that. It--
But it's that thing as well of... I don't know where they've got this information from.
But, I- kno- kno- kno- it's received--
Cuz you're not, so they're wrong.

Well it's- it's- yeah- they've received it from somewhere or they've- they've read it or something, it- it's just- I- I- but I don't know- I mean, I can't really be annoyed with it, they're just wrong. It's--
But it was very weird like--
It's- it's like being annoyed at a vicar believing in God, I can't get annoyed with him--
But because obviously they didn't recognize me, it's rather like- you know when they talk about the idea that if you could go to your funeral--
What would people be saying about you?
It's the closest thing you could get to that.
You- you can hear what people are saying about your friends.
But, why didn't you, um, g- get 'em 'round so you go- you go, "He is, yeah. What do you think of the other fella s- sometimes with him?"
"That tall fella. He's good, isn't he?"
It's- it's a shame, actually, because, umm, on the occasions I do get recognized for my minor appearances, umm, I never get any cool fans, I just get the nerds. I get the real nerdlingers.
I don't get, you know, beautiful women coming up--
You're putting them off, though. You're putting them off. You've got to take what you can.

Now, I know but this girl came up to me the other day and she said, "Hey, are you that guy who's involved with 'The Office'?", I go, "Why, yes I am", she went, "My boyfriend loves you, he's over here", and she pointed him out--
I was devastated. I thought, "I'm in here".

There was nothing- there was nothing going on. But there was a guy who was in HMV and he was working with a till- been working with a till and he saw me, he said, "Will you sign this DVD?", I went, "Ah, no problem", he- and I said- I was trying to make conversation- trying to be frothy and I said to him, "Awww, selling well is it?", and he went, "It is, it is. Although we've had quite a lot of returns".
I said, "Well, don't tell me that! I don't need to know that!"
What did he- what did he mean? That they didn't like it or that the--
And I said- I said, "What? People have been bringing them back?"--
He said, "They've been bringing them back", I said, "What was the problem?", he said, "They didn't really like it".
Yeah, "Some of 'em didn't really like it"!
(High Pitched) You can get it back if you don't like it?
I know! I mean, I don't know whether they gave them their money back but certainly that's what he dealt with- that's what he'd encountered.
Then he said, "We didn't give their money back, they just wanted to drop it off" "What, they didn't even want the money back?!"
(Laughing) Yeah. "They just wanted to get rid of it."
"They really didn't want it in the house."
"I don't want this rubbish in the house."
Awwww, but we still get the money for it, do we?
We still get the money but do you know that- I told you that time--

Again, because I'm- people don't recognize me, I was in a record shop, there was a stack of Office videos, and this guy went by and I, sort of, heard them as they went by. He went, "Oooh, Office. Yeah, a lot of people- lot of people like that. I think it's shit", his mate went, "I agree".
And of course, again I was- what could I do? I couldn't say anything. I couldn't pipe up and say, "Well, that's sort of... a bit of an insult".
(Laughing) What I like- I like these- the fact that you're always hearing these loud vocal--
(Laughing) That's great. What are the chances of two--
Maybe everyone's always slagging it off.
That's partly it but also because I keep stand- hanging out by stacks of Office DVDs.
(Laughing) Wearing a t-shirt with a picture of you and me on it.
What have we got to play, Karl?

Well, actually, um, I must dedicate this to, uh, someone who's emailed in. I mentioned earlier that I was going to play some of The Roots and Joe from Peterborough's very excited about that. So, uhh, this is not from the current Roots album, sadly, which I've not fully absorbed yet and therefore don't feel I can make a decision on which track to play but maybe that'll come up sometime in the future.
That's the sort of effort and thought we put into our- you know, picking music.
I had these cassettes still in my bag from last week.
(Laughing Slightly) Sure. Anyway, this is from the album "Things Fall Apart", it's The Roots featuring Erykah Badu "You Got Me". Let's play it.
The Roots feat. Erykah Badu - You Got Me
Featuring Erykah Badu, that's The Roots and "You Got Me".
Yeah, I love it, yeah. Well it's, uhh- it's coming up to 1:30 and so it's time for "Rockbusters".

It's a structured show, it's a new leaf. This show, in the new year, is gonna be structured - set pieces, um, hittin' our marks, do you know what I mean, there'll be time checks, uh- uhh, weather checks--
It's a bit cold out. Umm, if you're- if you're- if you're driving... careful and that.
Watch out for traffic, like, if it's bad.
Okay, well, again an abitrary selection of, uhh, goodies--
So, we've got, uhh, for those that are a fan of the movie "Donnie Darko" which a lot of people rave about this year, a sort of weird, teenage movie - then, uh, there's a sort of sweatshirt there.
It is actually quite nice. Long sleeve t-shirt--
It's not bad at all. It's, uhh- it's medium, so if you- if you're a bit of a bloater, don't bother to apply unless you've got a friend or relative.
Umm, uhh, we've also got here, uhhm, a Graham Norton video, certificate 18...
Please don't phone up unless you're- sorry, don't email in unless you're above the age of 18.
Umm, and that's, I think, the best of his TV show...
It's a big stiff video, that, innit? It's a big stiff cock of a video. Ooh!
You can't say- yeah. You meant the bird.
Fairly mediocre British wartime thriller, "Enigma", umm, which a lot of people r- r- it was hyped for a while but it's actually interminable - I've seen it.

Umm, the, uhh, first series here of "The Kumars at No. 42" on DVD. Uh, I think that's award-winning, so, uhh, that's available as well. We've got two CDs by the look of it. We've got, uhh, Pulp's greatest hits which I don't think sold very well and so presumably they are giving that away.
And Johnny Cash's, umm, current, uhh, album, uhh, "American IV: The Man Comes Around". There's some good cover versions there including--
Again, another big sell. A big sell. We're really pushing this.
Uh, but it- it- yeah, it's a quite kooky, uhh- Johnny Cash here does covers of things including "Personal Jesus"--
Uh, we've got "Bridge Over Troubled Water", his version of that.
"Desperado" and- anyway, it's not bad. That's probably the best treat in that bunch--
And, uhm, I'm assuming there's some questions there, Karl, are there?
Uh, if you're a new listener, the way it works - I give ya a cryptic clue--
And some initials and it sort of makes up a band--
Uhmm, makes more sense when you hear it, I reckon.
Well, not really. Although, people do get it. I just worry about the- the state of our listeners.
Right, so there's three of 'em, you email in [email protected]
I repeat: it is email only. We're not gonna have that--
We are too lazy to answer the phone!
Here we go then. Number One: uhm- there's- there's normally two easy ones and a difficult one.
So, here we go... Uhh, Number One: "Don't argue with him, he ain't gonna change his mind."
"Don't argue with him, he aint gonna change his mind."
That's- yeah. So, that's the first one.
"Don't argue with him, he ain't gonna change his mind."
What do you mean, "Uhm"?! You've presumably got them written out, haven't you?!
Just- just- I'm just thinkin' about... what the answer is because I didn't write the answer down to this one.
What do you mean? You can't remember it? You came up with it. There's only three!
I know, I know it's weird, innit?
No, it's not weird, it's incompetent.
Right, the second one, anyway, I hope you get this... Ehhm--
Email in and tell us the answer!
"He always gets what he wants and doesn't worry about anyone else." - P.
It'll- I'm sure- it'll come to me once I see it on email if- I know--
What do you mean?! Once they get it you'll agree with them?
I'll know if it's the one I had down as the answer.
Imagine Jeremy Paxman doing that, going--
Right, so, uhh, that's that one--
Uhm, "He always gets what he wants and doesn't worry about anyone else." - P.
But you're confused!... I don't understand how you can be confused.
All right, what's the final one?
The thir- the third one, uhh--
"I'll have to put that woman in the oven." And that's A.B.
All right, quickly give us them again.
Right, so the first one: "Don't argue with him, he ain't- he ain't gonna change his mind." That's A.A. Uhhmm--
"He always gets what he wants and doesn't worry about anyone else." That's P. And, uhhm, "I'll have to put that woman in the oven." - A.B.
I'm gonna play a classic track now by--
Neil Young, "Alabama"... A- Karl is still confused. He's waiting- he's biting his fingers, waiting for an email to tell him the answer to the clue he made up but can't get.
I love that as an experiment.
As a psycho- I mean, that would confuse psychologists - that you come up with something that you can't get. It's brilliant.
Yeah, you came up with a question, you don't know the answer.
And you expect them to but you can't and you made it up. Look at your face! Like a v- play some adverts.
"Honestly", Zwan. By, uhh, Billy Corgan's new band- there. Umm, ex-Smashing Pumpkins--
You'll be pleased to know, Rick, incidentally--
That someone's got the right answer. So, uhh, Karl--
Know's the band that's the answer.
It's a long time since we've had any "White Van Karl". For those that, uh, don't remember this particular hot feature--

Um, we basically ask s- Karl some of the questions that are asked of a white van driver, in "The Sun". They always have this on Saturday afternoon. Anyway, here's the first one- and they're not fascinating, Karl, but I'm just interested in your take, really.
What do you make of Cilla Black quitting "Blind Date" after her husband sent a message from beyond the grave. Are you familiar with this story?
She went to see a medium and, uhh, supposedly her husband passed on information through the medium which was incredibly vague but, uhm, persuaded her to quit live on air.
Well, so that- it's about time, innit? If even dead people are saying--
I'll tell you what though, talkin' about--
Talkin' about ghosts and that, do you know how I'm in to 'em?
Right. How weird do you think this is, right--
Well, it's not true. Before you say it.
I don't know if it's ghosts, really, it's just a bit weird.
And she's- well, she's not a woman, she's a kid.
She's walking down, uhh, like, a street in her area, it's a nice day and everything, everything's normal. Ehhm, she's walking down and a woman comes up cycling past, right?
The woman on the bike looks at the kid absolutely terrified.
Right? Got a really scary face on her.
The kid's thinking, "Why is she doing that?"
Right. So, anyway, she thinks nothing of- nothing of it, goes- you know, I think she was playing in the park or whatever- goes and has a nice day... 'Bout 15 years later--
She's- I don't know, I think she was going to work, all right, on her bike.
She's riding her own bike. Okay.
Riding her own bike. Cycling down the road--
Looks at the kid... That's the s- thing that happened, like, 15, 20 years ago--
It's her on the bike looking at her as a kid.
Right. Not- not- not another child?
So it's her. She's seen herself--
I mean, I don't know where to start.
Firstly, where's this information come from?

But, I mean, wh- why do you ever con- I mean- I don't know what part of that you think can be true. I- I don't- I- I m- honest- I- I'm speechless. I don't know what to say. What are you talking about?
It didn't happen. Nothing happened like that.
She saw herself as a kid, didn't she?
Did she carry on riding past?
And- and as an adult... when she was a kid.
(Laughing) And talk to herself? Or did she ride on by and think, "That's a bit weird, there's me as an 8-year-old. I won't stop, I'll be late for work"?
Yeah. Yeah. Yeah, if I'm late again the boss said he'd be in trouble.
And where is this information? Was it- did it happen to someone you know?
You overheard it on the bus.
No, it was, uhh- it was in "The Fortean Times".
We've got to the bottom of that.
And what do you make of David Blunkett accusing gangster rappers of making kids believe guns are cool? It's a hot topic there, Karl. I imagine you've got some, uh, strong opinions.
He is saying, basically, that all this rrrap music is, uh, advocating gun use, violence against people and he's very worried about it.
Have you thought about going into politics? Cuz...
I- I'll tell you this: they wouldn't be able to argue with you, really, in the houses of parliament.
Yeah. "My dear fellow, he's an idiot."
No, but violence has always been about, innit? Like, cowboys and indians, they didn't have playstations and Tupac then and there was still violence.
What do you mean? In the wild west?
D'ya know what I mean? So you can't really blame it on stuff- it'll- it'll always happen. That's, you know, that's the world, innit? It's made up of different types and that.
Again, he's right... Again, he's- he's sort of right, in a way. In his- in his innocence, in his buffoonery--
I didn't hear what he said.
He just said there's always been violence. You know what I mean? Sort of, like--
Even- you know, dinosaurs - look at them. They- they caused a lot of trouble.
And then he went too far and made himself--
No, but- but I'm just sayin', it's always happened, it always will.
Don't- you know, don't try and change it.
"Just chill out", is what you're saying.
Do you know what we should do? We should- we should all get on our bike go and find ourselves when we were little--
And go, "Be careful what you do in life."
Still good. On XFM 104.9. Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Karl Pilkington.
Ricky Anderson has, uh, emailed in.
He's, uh- he's probably our, uhh, biggest fan and--
(Laughing Slightly) Exactly. He's emailed in, as ever. "Ricky, your show fascinates me. How do you maintain such levels of senseless drivel?"
That's from, uhh- from Randers- from Randy Anders, little cl--
So, uh, thanks again, uhhh, um--
Uh, well done. He's, uh- yeah, that's great. Uh--
I get a buzz- A- A- I was dissapointed last week where he didn't- wh- wh- ask him why he's, uhh- didn't email us last--
Didn't- didn't- he didn't respond last week, no, it's a shame.
Probably busy. I don't believe he had something better to do.
Well, I wouldn't of thought so.
When, uh, you have this sort of level--
Not on a Saturday afternoon. Exactly.
Intense chat. What have you done this, uh, week, Karl?
Well, I've had a, uh- had a few days off, hadn't I?
Still, you know, doin' stuff for this show and that but--
Managed to put a few hours in--
Just- just doin'- doin' nothin' and, uh... bought a place. I was- I was lookin' at kitchens.
Checkin' them out and, uhh, also ordered a sofa...
Nice, sort of, comfy, sort of, leathe- leatherish sofa.
I don't- I don't like leather sofas. A l- a l--
No. Yeah, but what are you picturin'?
I don't li- it's squeakin', it's--
But I wa- I want a really old, sinkey--
Dented fabric- I wa- I want a sofa that is as comfortable as a bed.
Do you know what I mean?
Well if it was acceptable you'd have a bed in your lounge. Wouldn't you?
If that was allowed without seeming like you were, sort of, like, elderly or just--
That would be good. And I'd have- I'd have drip going in--
Sort of, like, with nutrients because you know I can't be bothered to chew--
Lager- sort of, lager with, sort of, uh, uhh, vitamins--
And then- and then one going from my knob down to the toilet--
A- And with all the remote controls.
And I- that would be amazing.
To be fair, you're almost there, Rick.
I've certainly seen the toilet tubing--
When I've been 'round in the past.
My dad's bed, right- my dad would never change his chair. My mum would try to get rid of it cuz it- it would just fit to him, it would just be absolutely dilapidated, right. And same his bed--
What, he's got his bed like his own chair in the lounge?
Yeah, his own chair, right. And, uhh.. and his bed right, when, uh - they had seperate rooms towards the end - um, and his bed, right- it was just- he had it for years and it was a big dip.
